articles.headline: Andrew M. Greeley, Priest, Scholar and Scold, Is Dead at 85
articles.snippet: Father Greeley’s outpouring of sociological research, contemporary theology, sexually frank novels and newspaper columns challenged reigning assumptions about American Catholicism.
articles.abstract: Father Greeley’s outpouring of sociological research, contemporary theology, sexually frank novels and newspaper columns challenged reigning assumptions about American Catholicism.
articles.lead_paragraph: Andrew M. Greeley, the Roman Catholic priest and writer whose outpouring of sociological research, contemporary theology, sexually frank novels and newspaper columns challenged reigning assumptions about American Catholicism, was found dead on Thursday morning at his home in Chicago. He was 85.

articles.headline: A Lone Voice Raises Alarms on Lucrative Diabetes Drugs
articles.snippet: Findings by Dr. Peter C. Butler on Merck’s medication Januvia are threatening the future of all drugs in its class, yearly sales of which exceed $9 billion.
articles.abstract: Findings by Dr. Peter C. Butler on Merck’s medication Januvia are threatening the future of all drugs in its class, yearly sales of which exceed $9 billion.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Dr. Peter C. Butler initially declined a request by the drug maker Merck to test whether its new diabetes drug, Januvia, could help stave off the disease in rats.

articles.headline: China’s Pork Deal May Hinge on the Risk for an Uproar
articles.snippet: A Chinese producer’s $4.7 billion deal for Smithfield is subject to a national security review, which is no picnic given American anxiety about China.
articles.abstract: A Chinese producer’s $4.7 billion deal for Smithfield is subject to a national security review, which is no picnic given American anxiety about China.
articles.lead_paragraph: Who knew that pork could be a national security problem?

articles.headline: Unions Press to End Special Trade Status for Bangladesh
articles.snippet: After several deadly factory disasters in Bangladesh, Obama administration officials remain conflicted over what measures would work best to improve labor conditions there.
articles.abstract: After several deadly factory disasters in Bangladesh, Obama administration officials remain conflicted over what measures would work best to improve labor conditions there.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After several deadly factory disasters in Bangladesh — including the collapse of an eight-story garment factory last month that left at least 1,127 people dead — labor advocates are stepping up pressure on the Obama administration, calling for it to convey its disapproval of working conditions in the country by revoking its special trade status.

articles.headline: This Time, a Growing Economy Stirs Unease
articles.snippet: Some argue for restraint in the face of a recovery in housing, interest rates and consumer confidence.
articles.abstract: Some argue for restraint in the face of a recovery in housing, interest rates and consumer confidence.
articles.lead_paragraph: The American markets are getting worried again. But this time the fear is refreshingly different.

articles.headline: Grim Task of Identifying Factories’ Dead Overwhelms Bangladeshi Lab
articles.snippet: Anger over the Rana Plaza collapse has intensified the pressure on a small lab struggling to make DNA matches with the remains of about 300 unidentified victims.
articles.abstract: Anger over the Rana Plaza collapse has intensified the pressure on a small lab struggling to make DNA matches with the remains of about 300 unidentified victims.
articles.lead_paragraph: DHAKA, Bangladesh — Inside a small government laboratory here, there are about 300 test tubes, each labeled with masking tape and containing an extracted tooth or a shard of bone. Day and night, dozens of these tubes rest on metal trays that vibrate with a motorized monotony. The shaking decalcifies the bone in a process that requires two weeks before material can be gleaned for a DNA profile.

articles.headline: Self-Driving Cars for Testing Are Supported by U.S.
articles.snippet: The Transportation Department said that driverless cars should not yet be allowed, except for testing, but noted that some safety features could save lives.
articles.abstract: The Transportation Department said that driverless cars should not yet be allowed, except for testing, but noted that some safety features could save lives.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Companies from Silicon Valley to Detroit to Germany are developing cars that park, steer and even drive themselves. Now the federal agency for traffic safety has said it wants to come along for the ride.
articles.byline: By Claire Cain Miller and Matthew L. Wald

articles.headline: Promising African Development Fund Collapses
articles.snippet: A program financed by the Agency for International Development is dissolving because of mismanagement, insider dealings and a lack of federal oversight.
articles.abstract: A program financed by the Agency for International Development is dissolving because of mismanagement, insider dealings and a lack of federal oversight.
articles.lead_paragraph: The initiative began two decades ago, with the best of intentions, after apartheid fell and southern Africa’s future brightened.
articles.byline: By Barry Meier and Ron Nixon

articles.headline: A New Step in Wrestling With the Bra
articles.snippet: Jockey has devised a new way to measure bra sizes and is offering a $20 kit to help women get a better fit, in what could be a mass-market answer to custom fittings popular among women in boutiques and high-end department stores.
articles.abstract: Jockey has devised a new way to measure bra sizes and is offering a $20 kit to help women get a better fit, in what could be a mass-market answer to custom fittings popular among women in boutiques and high-end department stores.
articles.lead_paragraph: They are the measurements that many American women (and not a few American men) know so well: 32A, 34B, 36C.

articles.headline: German From Senegal Vies to Break Bundestag Barrier
articles.snippet: Karamba Diaby, a Social Democrat who became a German citizen in 2001, could become the first black member of Parliament.
articles.abstract: Karamba Diaby, a Social Democrat who became a German citizen in 2001, could become the first black member of Parliament.
articles.lead_paragraph: HALLE, Germany — When Karamba Diaby arrived in Germany as a student from Senegal he knew only two things in German: Bundesliga and BMW — the professional soccer league and the automobile manufacturer. The only hitch was that it was October 1985 and Mr. Diaby had landed in East Germany, where comrades frowned on both West German capitalist institutions.

articles.headline: Report Shows Better Outlook for Medicare
articles.snippet: A stronger economy and slower growth in health spending have helped strengthen the financial outlook for the federal insurance program, the Obama administration said.
articles.abstract: A stronger economy and slower growth in health spending have helped strengthen the financial outlook for the federal insurance program, the Obama administration said.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The financial outlook for Medicare has improved because of a stronger economy and slower growth in health spending, and the financial condition of Social Security has not worsened but is still unsustainable, the Obama administration said Friday.
